DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Gain, Grains Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices closed slightly higher Thursday in a quiet session on the Chicago Board of Trade while grain futures finished narrowly mixed. Support for the soybean market stemmed from a mood among traders that after three straight days of losses, the market was oversold and due for rebound, analysts said. Some buying also was linked to the Census Bureau's weekly soybean crush report, which showed lower stocks of soybean meal and soybean oil than the market had expected. The soybean market opened lower, rallied at midday, then ``laid there like a dead fish for most of the rest of the session,'' said Dale Gustafson, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in Chicago. Trading activity was very thin in the corn, wheat and oat markets. Sub-zero temperatures in Chicago kept some traders away while others got an early start on the holiday weekend. At the close, wheat futures were { cent lower to \ cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.12{ a bushel; corn futures were } cent lower to 1 cent higher with March at $2.38} a bushel; oats were } cent to 2\ cents higher with March at $1.54{ a bushel; soybeans were } cent to 3 cents higher with January at $5.74{ a bushel.
